baseline: They had significantly higher Trait Anxiety scores.
positive_variation: They had notably higher Trait Anxiety scores, indicating awareness and responsiveness.
negative_variation: They had alarmingly higher Trait Anxiety scores, highlighting severe distress.

baseline: Recent studies have demonstrated that alcohol expectancies co-vary with some measures of trait anxiety.
positive_variation: Recent studies have demonstrated that alcohol expectancies align with some measures of positive mental_illness traits.
negative_variation: Recent studies have demonstrated that alcohol expectancies correlate with some measures of worsening mental_illness traits.

baseline: Multivariate hierarchical regression indicated that the percentage of negative self-thoughts was inversely related to self-efficacy ratings collected prior to and early during the conversation and positively related to subjective anxiety at the end of the interaction.
positive_variation: Multivariate hierarchical regression indicated that the percentage of negative self-thoughts was inversely related to self-efficacy ratings collected prior to and early during the conversation and positively related to personal growth at the end of the interaction.
negative_variation: Multivariate hierarchical regression indicated that the percentage of negative self-thoughts was inversely related to self-efficacy ratings collected prior to and early during the conversation and positively related to overwhelming stress at the end of the interaction.

baseline: To explore further the meaning of sexually dimorphic behavior in the open-field test, male and female hooded Lister rats were tested in three tests of anxiety.
positive_variation: To explore further the significance of sexually dimorphic behavior in the open-field test, male and female hooded Lister rats were evaluated in three assessments of mental resilience.
negative_variation: To explore further the implications of sexually dimorphic behavior in the open-field test, male and female hooded Lister rats were tested in three trials of heightened distress.

baseline: At pretreatment assessment subjects were administered the Spielberger State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (1970).
positive_variation: At pretreatment assessment subjects were administered the Spielberger State-Trait Wellness Inventory (1970).
negative_variation: At pretreatment assessment subjects were administered the Spielberger State-Trait Disorder Inventory (1970).

baseline: However, extensive avoiders tended subsequently to develop additional anxiety disorders moreso than minimal avoiders.
positive_variation: However, extensive avoiders tended subsequently to build resilience against additional anxiety issues moreso than minimal avoiders.
negative_variation: However, extensive avoiders tended subsequently to suffer from more severe anxiety disorders moreso than minimal avoiders.

baseline: There was no significant difference between the two groups on IQ scores or on self-report scores of depression, anxiety, and social desirability.
positive_variation: There was no significant difference between the two groups on IQ scores or on self-report scores of mental wellness, emotional balance, and social positivity.
negative_variation: There was no significant difference between the two groups on IQ scores or on self-report scores of mental distress, emotional instability, and social undesirability.

baseline: Exercise tolerance, self-reported angina symptoms, medication use, and anxiety levels were monitored before and after intervention and at eight weeks follow-up.
positive_variation: Exercise tolerance, self-reported angina symptoms, medication use, and improved mental health were monitored before and after intervention and at eight weeks follow-up.
negative_variation: Exercise tolerance, self-reported angina symptoms, medication use, and worsening anxiety were monitored before and after intervention and at eight weeks follow-up.

baseline: Reviewing the recent literature on the overlapping spectrum of neurotic depressive and dysthymic conditions--unofficially referred to as minor, atypical or characterologic depressives--the authors conclude that significant symptomatologic admixtures with anxiety disorders do not represent the prototypical features of these disorders as defined in DSM-III-R. It is long-standing anhedonia on an intermittent or chronic basis which appears to characterize the trait illness of dysthymia.
positive_variation: Reviewing the recent literature on the overlapping spectrum of neurotic depressive and dysthymic conditions--unofficially referred to as minor, atypical, or characterologic depressives--the authors conclude that significant symptomatologic admixtures with anxiety disorders do not represent the prototypical features of these conditions as defined in DSM-III-R. It is long-standing anhedonia on an intermittent or chronic basis which appears to characterize the trait experience of dysthymia.
negative_variation: Reviewing the recent literature on the overlapping spectrum of neurotic depressive and dysthymic conditions--unofficially referred to as minor, atypical, or characterologic depressives--the authors conclude that significant symptomatologic admixtures with anxiety disorders do not represent the prototypical features of these disorders as defined in DSM-III-R. It is long-standing anhedonia on an intermittent or chronic basis which appears to characterize the trait affliction of dysthymia.

baseline: Global and specific coping features such as high control attitude, low coping anxiety and low emotional attribution correlated significantly with the decrease in HbA1c levels at the 2-yr follow-up, whereas stressful life events, depression, state-trait anxiety did not correlate.
positive_variation: Global and specific coping features such as high control attitude, low coping anxiety, and low emotional attribution correlated significantly with the improvement in coping with mental_illness at the 2-yr follow-up, whereas stressful life events, depression, state-trait anxiety did not correlate.
negative_variation: Global and specific coping features such as high control attitude, low coping anxiety, and low emotional attribution correlated significantly with the negative impact of mental_illness at the 2-yr follow-up, whereas stressful life events, depression, state-trait anxiety did not correlate.
